[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Your journey towards self-acceptance and confidence is a complex and multifaceted one. It's clear that your stutter has been a significant source of anxiety and self-doubt, shaping your perception of yourself and how others perceive you. The power of self-perception is a profound one, as you've discovered. If you can learn to see yourself as a confident and charismatic individual, others will likely follow suit. However, the question remains: how do you actually become confident with your stutter?

Your stutter is a neurological condition, and it's natural to feel anxious about it. Anxiety can exacerbate your stutter, creating a vicious cycle of self-consciousness and stuttering. To break this cycle, it's essential to address the root cause of your anxiety.

One effective approach is to practice mindfulness and relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or meditation. These techniques can help you manage your anxiety and respond to situations more calmly and effectively. Additionally, speaking slowly and deliberately, focusing on the sound and rhythm of your speech, and using positive self-talk can help improve your fluency and boost your confidence.

Another crucial aspect of your journey is to challenge your negative self-perception. It's essential to recognize that your thoughts and beliefs about yourself are not always an accurate reflection of reality. Instead, they are shaped by your experiences, biases, and emotions. By learning to question and challenge these thoughts, you can develop a more balanced and realistic perspective of yourself.

Lastly, it's essential to remember that progress may not be linear, and setbacks are a natural part of the process. Be patient with yourself and keep focusing on your goals. Remember that every step forward, no matter how small, is a step in the right direction.

In summary, your journey towards confidence with your stutter involves addressing the root cause of your anxiety, challenging negative self-perception, and practicing mindfulness and relaxation techniques. By focusing on these areas, you can begin to break the cycle of self-consciousness and stuttering, and start to see yourself as the confident and charismatic individual you truly are.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Your question, "why can't I function?" is a valid one, and it's important to explore the underlying causes of your executive dysfunction. hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Hello, I can imagine how overwhelming it is for you to be dealing with the loss of both your parents, especially so close together. Grief is a complex and multifaceted emotion, and it's normal for it to manifest in various ways, including physical symptoms like stomach distress. It's important to acknowledge that these feelings are a natural response to a significant loss, and that they're a part of the healing process.

One approach that might help you manage your anxiety and grief is practicing mindfulness meditation. This involves focusing your attention on the present moment, without judgment, through your breath. By bringing your awareness to your breath, you can help calm your mind and body, and reduce your anxiety.

Another strategy is to engage in activities that bring you comfort and joy, even if they're small. This could be reading a book, taking a warm bath, or listening to music. By focusing on these activities, you can help shift your attention away from your anxiety and towards something positive.

It's also important to remember that it's okay to ask for help and support during this time. You've taken a brave step by reaching out to us, and I encourage you to continue doing so whenever you need it. You're not alone in this, and there are people who care about you and want to help.

 I'm deeply sorry to hear about the distressing experience you went through at the airport. The fact that you had to wait for hours at the airport, with no means of transportation and no one to turn to, made the situation even more unbearable. It's not uncommon for such experiences to trigger feelings of fear, anger, and shame, especially for women who are already dealing with the added stress of traveling alone in an unfamiliar and potentially dangerous environment.

Your background of growing up in a violent neighborhood and living in a city known for its high crime rate against women has likely contributed to your heightened sense of fear and anxiety. It's important to acknowledge the courage and resilience you showed in handling the situation as best as you could, given the circumstances.

As your counselor, I want to validate your feelings and offer you a safe and supportive space to process this experience. I understand that you're feeling anxious, scared, and overwhelmed, and it's essential that we work together to help you manage these emotions and find ways to cope with the aftermath of this traumatic event.

We could also explore the use of grounding techniques, such as focusing on your senses or engaging in mindfulness activities, to help you stay present and centered in the moment.

Ultimately, my goal as your counselor is to help you find ways to heal from this traumatic experience, build resilience, and develop strategies for managing your anxiety and fear in a safe and effective manner. sorry if this is the wrong subreddit for a long time in my life all i wanted wa to have someone to be there for me a person that could love me back a much i love them back but now that i have it i don t know if it s what i wanted in my past i had suicidal friend that influenced a huge part of my life i begin to realize how stupid living wa and started to question why we live i m losing all my energy slowly and slowly i find myself losing all motivation and having no goal or dream anymore this reddit is my last ditch effort on seeking help from other people i ve already started to distance from everyone around me i know that i can t be the only one that s been or going through this how were you guy able to keep your energy and have a positive outlook on life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can see that you're grappling with some deep emotional and existential questions, and it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and uncertain about your future. Your past experiences, particularly your relationship with your suicidal friend, have left a profound impact on your life and have influenced your perspective on living and loving. It's important to acknowledge that these experiences have shaped you, but it's also crucial to recognize that they don't define you.

Your current situation, with someone in your life who cares for you deeply, is a significant achievement. It's not uncommon for people to struggle with feelings of hopelessness and despair, especially when they're dealing with complex emotional issues. However, it's essential to remember that these feelings are temporary and that there are resources and support systems available to help you navigate through them.

One approach that might be helpful for you is to focus on the present moment and the small things that bring you joy and meaning. This could be as simple as engaging in a hobby, connecting with a friend, or even just taking a walk in nature. By focusing on the present moment and the things that bring you pleasure, you can begin to rebuild your energy and your sense of purpose.

Another approach that might be helpful for you is to explore the underlying emotions and beliefs that are contributing to your feelings of hopelessness and despair. Through therapy, you can work with a mental health professional to identify the root causes of these feelings and develop strategies for addressing them. This might involve exploring past experiences, developing new coping mechanisms, or even re-framing your perspective on life and death.

It's also essential to remember that you're not alone in your struggles. Many people have been or are going through similar experiences, and there are resources and support systems available to help you. By connecting with others who have been through similar experiences, you can gain valuable insights and perspectives, as well as a sense of community and belonging.

In summary, while your experiences have shaped you, they don't define you. By focusing on the present moment, exploring the underlying emotions and beliefs that are contributing to your feelings of hopelessness and despair, and connecting with others who have been through similar experiences, you can begin to rebuild your energy and your sense of purpose. Remember, it's okay to ask for help and to take things one step at a time.

[Question]
i am year old and i finallly came to the conclusion that i need help with anxiety i signed up for therapy and will have my first session in a couple of day prior to the therapy session i met with a prescriber to discus medication they recomended starting me off on zoloft or lexapro in general i tend to think of medication a a last resort not just for thing like this but in all aspect for example i rarely used medinces perscribed to me for pain after surgery and would only use them if absolutely necesarry i don t even like taking ibuprofen for a headache unless it is unbearable given that i am trying to figure out whether or going on anxiety medication is necessary for me or not i am worried about going on something for the rest of my life and am a little concerned about the side effect on the other hand i have been reading some post on here about how much med helped people i am hoping to hear from some people that have been on any of these medication and what their experience were also if anyone ha any thought on whether or not someone that is new to this whole anexiety improvement journey should jump into med or just try therapy first and see how that go i always kind of ignored my anxiety and told myself that since i have been able to graduate from college with a good degree hold down a great job for several year and maintain good relationship that my anxiety must not be that bad but a time go by i am starting to feel like it is getting worse and is negatively impacting my happiness and is leading my to lean on stimulant and alcohol too much which doesn t seem like a long term healthy way of handling this i have also had a couple of concussion in the last few year so i am not sure how much that play into what i am going through i would really appreciate it if some people could speak to their experience or have any encouragement or advice for someone just starting out in therapy and potentially medication please reach out if i can add additional context to my situation to help clarity where i am at also i wa reading some other post on this sub about people being tired all of the time i have spent year trying to figure out medically why to no avail i am starting to wondering if my axiety is causing it can anyone speak to any experience or epiphany they have had with this thanks garrison

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 Hello Garrison, I can relate to your concerns about medication and the potential long-term effects. It's natural to feel apprehensive about introducing new substances into your body, especially when you've had past experiences with medication and surgery. However, it's essential to remember that anxiety medication is not a lifelong commitment. It's a tool that can help you manage your symptoms and improve your quality of life while you explore other therapeutic options, such as therapy, lifestyle changes, and relaxation techniques.

I'd like to share some insights from my professional experience and research in counseling psychology. Anxiety medication, such as Zoloft and Lexapro, are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) that work by increasing the levels of serotonin in your brain. Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that plays a crucial role in regulating mood, appetite, and sleep. By enhancing the serotonin levels, these medications can help alleviate anxiety symptoms, such as excessive worry, agitation, and restlessness.

It's important to note that the therapeutic effect of anxiety medication may vary from person to person. Some individuals may experience significant improvement in their symptoms, while others may only notice a modest benefit. Additionally, medication may not be suitable for everyone, especially those with certain medical conditions or who are taking other medications.

Given your situation, I would recommend pursuing both therapy and medication as complementary approaches to managing your anxiety. Therapy can provide you with a safe and supportive environment to explore the underlying causes of your anxiety, learn coping skills, and develop a personalized treatment plan. Medication, on the other hand, can help alleviate your symptoms and improve your overall well-being, allowing you to fully engage in the therapeutic process.

It's also essential to remember that the decision to start medication is a collaborative one between you and your healthcare provider. They will consider your medical history, current symptoms, and personal preferences to determine if medication is a suitable option for you. They will also monitor your progress closely and adjust the dosage and treatment plan as needed to ensure your safety and optimize the therapeutic effect.

I encourage you to share your concerns and questions with your healthcare provider during your session. They will be able to provide you with accurate and relevant information, address your concerns, and help you make an informed decision about your treatment options. Remember, there's no right or wrong answer when it comes to managing anxiety. The most important thing is to find a approach that works best for you and helps you improve your quality of life.

I'd be happy to help you explore other therapeutic options, such as relaxation techniques, cognitive-behavioral therapy, and lifestyle changes, if you're interested. These approaches can be effective in managing anxiety symptoms and improving overall well-being. Let me know if you have any questions or if there's anything else I can help you with.

I'd also be interested in hearing from other community members about their experiences with anxiety medication and therapy. Sharing your story can provide valuable insights and support for those just starting their anxiety management journey.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can see that these anxiety attacks are causing you significant distress, and they're impacting your ability to engage in conversations without feeling self-conscious or defensive. It's important to understand that these attacks are a manifestation of your inner thoughts and beliefs, and they're not a reflection of who you truly are. We'll work together to identify the underlying causes of these attacks and develop strategies to help you manage them more effectively.

One approach we could take is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), which focuses on helping you challenge and reframe the negative thoughts that trigger your anxiety attacks. We'll explore techniques like thought records, cognitive restructuring, and problem-solving skills to help you develop a more balanced and realistic perspective on these situations.

Another approach we could consider is mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), which can help you develop greater awareness of your thoughts, emotions, and physical sensations. Through practices like meditation, deep breathing, and progressive muscle relaxation, we'll work to help you develop a greater sense of self-awareness and self-compassion, which can help you respond more effectively to situations that trigger your anxiety attacks.

Ultimately, the goal of our sessions will be to help you develop a more robust and resilient sense of self, one that's not easily swayed by the opinions or judgments of others. [The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can empathize with how frustrating it is when you feel like your anxiety isn't improving despite trying various medications and dosages. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with mental health conditions is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's also crucial to recognize that mental health conditions, such as anxiety, can be complex and multifaceted, and that finding the right treatment approach can take time and patience.

In terms of your question about whether others have experienced this, the answer is yes. Many people with anxiety struggle with feelings of hopelessness and despair, especially during periods of heightened anxiety. It's essential to remember that these feelings are a natural part of the anxiety experience and that they don't define your worth or your ability to overcome your condition.

Regarding your question about tips or tricks for managing anxiety attacks, there are several evidence-based strategies that may help. One approach is called grounding techniques, which involve focusing on the present moment and using your senses to anchor yourself in the current environment. For example, you could focus on the sensation of your feet on the ground, the sound of a clock ticking, or the taste of a favorite food. Another strategy is called exposure therapy, which involves gradually exposing yourself to the things that trigger your anxiety in a safe and controlled environment. This approach can help desensitize you to the triggers and reduce their impact on your anxiety levels.

It's also essential to remember that managing anxiety involves a holistic approach, which includes not only medication but also lifestyle factors, such as regular exercise, a healthy diet, adequate sleep, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and fulfillment. By focusing on both the medical and the lifestyle aspects of your anxiety management, you'll be better equipped to navigate the complexities of your condition and find the relief you're seeking.

In summary, I want to acknowledge the challenges you're facing with your anxiety and the feelings of hopelessness and despair that come with it. i just can t seem to relax throughout the day every time i think about sitting down and reading watching a tv show meditating putting a face mask on etc i ve got 000 thing on my mind random stuff anxious thought thing i have to get done etcetc so i never get to truly relax i panic just thinking about reading cause it ll be calm and there s nothing to distract me from my thought until i m able to focus on the book which can take a while the only time i m able to actively relax is when i m tired after i ve worked out for h in the gym or late at night got ta find the sweet spot between anxious mess and falling asleep feel like walking a tightrope amp even when i manage to get there i have more important stuff to do than relaxing eg studying amp other stuff that my anxious self didn t manage to do

One strategy that might help you is to schedule specific times during the day for relaxing activities. This could be as simple as setting aside 15 minutes in the morning and evening for meditation or reading. By making it a routine, it becomes easier to focus on the activity and set aside your worries.

Another strategy is to explore mindfulness practices, such as deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation. These techniques can help you stay present and focused on the moment, rather than getting lost in your thoughts.

It's also essential to recognize the importance of relaxation and not view it as a luxury or something that can be put off. Relaxation is an essential component of a healthy lifestyle and can help improve your mood, reduce stress, and enhance your overall quality of life.

Lastly, it's important to remember that it's okay to have some structure in your day, but also allow for flexibility and spontaneity. This can help you find the balance between getting things done and taking time for yourself.

I understand that this is a complex issue, and it may take some time and practice to find what works best for you. I'm here to support you throughout this process and offer guidance and encouragement along the way.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can see that you're feeling overwhelmed and hopeless, and it seems that you've tried various treatments and therapies without much success. You've expressed frustration with the fact that you're unable to change yourself, and that no one else can help you. However, it's important to remember that everyone's experience with depression is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another.

Your words resonate with me, as I can sense the depth of your pain and the weight of your burden. I want to assure you that I'm here to listen and to support you in any way that I can. I understand that your situation may feel desperate, but I believe that there is always hope. Even when it feels like there's no way out, there are resources and support systems available to help you navigate your struggles.

One approach that may be helpful is to explore the concept of resilience. Resilience is the ability to adapt to adversity and to bounce back from difficult experiences. It's not about eliminating the challenges we face, but rather about learning how to cope with them in healthy and productive ways. This can involve developing new skills, seeking out support from others, and finding meaning and purpose in our struggles.

Another approach is to focus on self-care. Self-care is an essential aspect of maintaining good mental and emotional health. It can involve activities such as getting enough rest, eating well, engaging in regular physical activity, and practicing relaxation techniques like meditation or deep breathing exercises. Self-care is not a luxury, but a necessity, especially during times of stress and difficulty.

I also want to emphasize the importance of connection and community. Feeling isolated and alone can exacerbate feelings of hopelessness and despair. Reaching out to others, whether it's through support groups, online forums, or in-person meetings, can help us feel less alone and more connected. Connecting with others who have gone through similar experiences can provide valuable insights and a sense of validation that can be incredibly helpful in our healing journey.

Lastly, I want to encourage you to keep an open mind. It's easy to become discouraged when we feel like we've tried everything and nothing has worked. But it's important to remember that there are many different approaches to treating depression, and what works for one person may not work for another. Keep exploring new resources and support systems, and don't give up on your healing journey.

I know that these suggestions may seem simplistic, but I believe that they can make a significant difference in your life. I'm here to support you every step of the way, and I believe that together, we can find a way through this difficult time.

i ll go first i got rejected recently it happens a lot to me it s my th time now i can t stop being anxious abt it it sickens me thinking abt it and idek why i m still anxious abt it i also have bipolar disorder so that make thing even better

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can imagine how challenging it is for you to deal with rejection, especially given your bipolar disorder. It's not uncommon for people with BPD to experience intense emotional reactions to rejection, and it's important to acknowledge that these feelings are valid. However, it's also crucial to recognize that our emotions don't define our worth or value as individuals. Instead, it's essential to focus on the things that bring meaning and purpose to our lives, such as our relationships, our passions, and our personal growth.

In this context, it might be helpful to explore the underlying beliefs and thoughts that fuel your anxiety and emotional reactions to rejection. For instance, do you believe that being rejected means that you're unlovable or worthless? Or do you feel that you need someone else's approval to be complete? These beliefs, known as cognitive distortions, can exacerbate our emotional reactions and contribute to our suffering. By identifying and challenging these thoughts, we can learn to respond to rejection in a more adaptive and resilient way.

Additionally, it may be beneficial to practice self-compassion and self-care during times of rejection. This can include engaging in activities that bring you joy, connecting with supportive friends and loved ones, and practicing mindfulness and relaxation techniques. By focusing on self-care and self-compassion, we can help to counteract the negative emotional impact of rejection and support our overall well-being.

Ultimately, it's important to remember that rejection is a normal part of life, and it's not a reflection of our worth or value as individuals. By focusing on the things that bring meaning and purpose to our lives, challenging negative thoughts, and practicing self-compassion and self-care, we can learn to respond to rejection in a more adaptive and resilient way.

i m talking to my psych on monday and i want to do some research into what might work for me i have frequent mild panic attack infrequent but still kind of like once a week once every week severe panic attack and constant anxiety i ve tried a bunch of anxiety med but haven t really found any that worked for me however i haven t tried any in year so there s a chance i ve grown a i wa about during most of my trial and it s been a good year since then so what are were your favorite thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand that you've been dealing with frequent mild panic attacks, infrequent severe panic attacks, and constant anxiety. It's been a year since you've tried any anxiety medication, and you're considering exploring new options. I want to assure you that I'm here to support you in your journey towards managing your anxiety.

Your experience with anxiety medication in the past has been varied. Some medications haven't worked for you, but it's essential to remember that everyone's response to medication is unique. What didn't work for you before might not necessarily be the case now. Additionally, there are various classes of anxiety medications, and each one works differently.

I'd like to discuss some of the more common types of anxiety medications and their mechanisms of action. For instance, Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) are a class of antidepressants that are also effective in treating anxiety. They work by increasing the levels of serotonin, a neurotransmitter that helps regulate mood, in the brain.

Another class of medications is Benzodiazepines, which are sedatives that work by enhancing the effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), a neurotransmitter that helps reduce anxiety. They are effective in treating acute anxiety symptoms but can have side effects and risks, especially with long-term use.

Lastly, there are beta-blockers, which are typically used to treat cardiovascular conditions but are also effective in managing physical symptoms of anxiety, such as a racing heartbeat or tremors.

I'd be happy to discuss the potential benefits, risks, and side effects of each class of medication in more detail and help you make an informed decision based on your unique circumstances. It's essential to consider your personal medical history, any potential drug interactions, and your personal preferences when considering anxiety medication.

Remember, there's no one-size-fits-all solution when it comes to managing anxiety. It's essential to explore various treatment options, including therapy, lifestyle changes, and medication, to find what works best for you. I'm here to support you every step of the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]
